place.name: CLAY CROSS
place.gazetteerText: CLAYCROSS, or Claylane, a township and a chapelry in North Wingfield parish, Derby. The township lies on the Midland railway, 4½ miles S of Chesterfield; and has a station on the railway, and a post office‡ under Chesterfield, both of the name of Claycross. Pop., 4, 096. Houses, 709. The chapelry was constituted in 1852, and is more extensive than the township. Rated property, £8, 213. Pop., 4, 922. Houses, 875. The property is much subdivided. Extensive collieries and iron-works are here; and have British schools, with institute and public hall, built at a cost of £4, 000. The living is a vicarage in the diocese of Lichfield. Value, £300.* Patron, the Rector of North Wingfield. The church was built in 1851, and is in the early English style. There are three Methodist chapels. (In 1870-72, John Marius Wilson's Imperial Gazetteer of England and Wales)
